Find the common difference, $d$. [2]



Find $u8​$. [2]

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
Bruno rides his bike to school each morning. During the first minute, he travels $160$ metres. In each subsequent minute, he travels $80%$ of the distance travelled during the previous minute.
The distance from his home to school is $750$ metres. Bruno leaves his house at $8$:$30$ am and must be at school by $8$:$40$ am.

Verify that Bruno will not arrive at school on time. [3]


Bruno realises that if he can increase the distance he travels each minute, from $80%$ of the distance travelled during the previous minute to $k%$, he will make it to school on time.

Determine the minimum value of $k$, given that Bruno still travels $160m$ in the first minute. [3]
list.markScheme:
We could consider each minute of Bruno's journey as a term of a geometric sequence, and we need the sum of the first 10 terms to determine how far Bruno travels between $8$:$30$ and $8$:$40$ am.
We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u1​=160$ and common ratio $r=0.8$.
If we use the sum of $n$ terms formula $Sn​=1−ru1​(1−rn)​$ with $n=10$, we get
$$$S10​714.10...​=1−ru1​(1−r10)​=1−0.8160(1−0.810)​=714.10...<750​(M1)A1R1​$$$
Bruno will only travel $714$ metres by $8$:$40$ am, which is less than the $750$ metres required.
Therefore, Bruno $will not$ arrive at school on time.


Again, we require the sum of the first 10 terms of a geometric sequence with first term $u1​=160$. This sum must be $at least$ 750 to ensure that Bruno will make it to school on time. We do not know the common ratio, but if each minute Bruno travels $k%$ of the distance travelled in the previous minute, then we will have a common ratio of $r=100k​$.
Using this information we can form an inequality.
$$$S10​1−100k​160(1−(100k​)10)​​≥750≥750​(M1)​$$$
To solve this, we can sketch both sides of the inequality and find the point of intersection.
$$$​(M1)​$$$

list.title: Question 37
list.content:
A bouncy ball is dropped out of a second story classroom window,  $5$m off the ground. Every time the ball hits the ground it bounces $89$% of its previous height.


Find the height the ball reaches after the $2$nd bounce. [2]



Find the total distance the ball has travelled when it hits the ground for the $5$th time. [3]
list.markScheme:
The height of the ball after each bounce follows a geometric sequence, with first term $u1​=5(0.89)$ and common ratio $r=0.89$.
Using the formula for the $n$th term of a geometric sequence, we have
$$$u2​​=u1​r2−1=[5(0.89)](0.89)1≈3.96 m​​$$$


The total distance travelled by the ball is the sum of two separate geometric sequences.
The first, when the ball is travelling downwards, has first term $u1​=5$ and common ratio $r=0.89$. When the ball hits the ground for the $5$th time, it has travelled downwards a distance that is equivalent to the sum of the first five terms of this sequence. We have
$$$Sn​S5​​=1−ru1​(1−rn)​=1−0.895(1−0.895)​≈20.07m​$$$
The second, when the ball is travelling upwards, has first term $u1​=5(0.89)$ and common ratio $r=0.89$. When the ball hits the ground for the $5$th time, it has travelled upwards a distance that is equivalent to the sum of the first four terms of this sequence. We have
$$$Sn​S4​​=1−ru1​(1−rn)​=1−0.895(0.89)(1−0.894)​≈15.07m​$$$
The total distance travelled is given by $20.07+15.07$.
The total distance travelled by the ball is approximately $35.1metres​$.

Aoife and Barack have both started a delivery job, where they are paid the same amount daily to make a certain number of deliveries.
On the first day, both Aoife and Barack take 240 minutes to make their deliveries.
Aoife plans to reduce the amount of time the deliveries take by 2 minutes per day.
Barack plans to reduce the amount of time the deliveries take by $1%$ per day.

The time Aoife takes daily to complete her deliveries follows an $arithmetic sequence$, with first term $u1​=240$ and common difference $d=−2$.
The time Barack takes daily to complete his deliveries follows a $geometric sequence$ with first term $v1​=240$ and common ratio $r$.
Given that Barack is $reducing$ his time by $1%$ per day, this means that each day his deliveries take $99%$ of the time of the day before. Therefore $r=0.99$.
We are looking for the first day that Aoife will complete her deliveries faster than Barack. Let's call this day $n$.
We are therfore looking for the smallest value of $n$ such that $un​<vn​$.
Using the formula for the $n$th term of an arithmetic sequence, we have
$$$un​un​​=u1​+(n−1)d=240+(n−1)(−2)=240−2n+2=242−2n​(A1)​$$$
Using the formula for the $n$th term of a geometric sequence, we have
$$$vn​​=v1​rn−1=240(0.99)n−1​(A1)​$$$
Hence we are trying determine the smallest value of $n$ so that
$$$242−2n<240(0.99)n−1​(A1)​$$$
To do this, we will sketch and interpret the graphs of $y=242−2x$ and $y=240(0.99)x−1$:
$$$​(M1)$$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5abb56ff-0206-43c0-b41f-d8df69082b2f/images/0aeaebcb-92b3-42b0-a61a-20bb9a72a750/1179.JPG)


We see that the graphs intersect at $(39.52,163.0)$.
$$$​(A1)$$$
Let's look at the nearest whole numbers to the left and right of $x=39.52$.
When $x=39$, the red line is slightly $above$ the green curve.
When $x=40$, now the red line is slightly $below$ the green curve.
In the context of our question, this means that on day 39, Barack completed his deliveries slightly quicker than Aoife.
On day 40, Aoife completed her deliveries slightly quicker than Barack, and this was the first time it happened.
$Day 40 is the first day on which Aoife completes her deliveries faster than Barack.​$
$$$​A1$$$

list.title: Question 48
list.content:
Jenni is conducting an experiment with a spring and has attached a mass so that it will oscillate up and down.
She is measuring the $y$-coordinate of the centre of the mass.
At the start of the experiment the mass is at rest with its centre being at the point $(0,0)$.
She gives the mass a nudge upwards in the positive $y$-direction. She makes her first measurement of $(0,37.5)$ when the centre of the mass is at the first maximum point ($n=1$). The units of the $y$-coordinate are in millimetres.
The mass then moves downwards passing the $x$-axis and reaching its first minimum point ($n=2$). Jenni makes her second measurement of the $y$-coordinate of the centre of a the mass as $(0,a)$.
The mass then moves up past the $x$-axis to the next maximum point ($n=3$) and Jenni makes her third measurement of $(0,24)$.
The diagram below shows how the mass moves up and down until Jenni makes her $3$rd measurement.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5c432714-26e0-44d2-ad4c-8fbd32ef03e2/images/e1e394ce-c8ff-476f-b471-b3fad49316a7/springs.png)


Jenni notices that the $y$-coordinates of the three measurements $37.5,a,24$ form a geometric sequence.

Find $a$. [2]


The spring continues to oscillate up and down with Jenni measuring the $y$-coordinate in the same way as described.
The results continue to form a geometric sequence.


Find the $6$th term in the sequence. Give your answer to 3 decimal places. [2]



Show that the total distance travelled in the $y$-direction by the mass when the $6$th measurement is made is  $264.408$ mm. [3]
list.markScheme:
Let the common ratio of the sequence be $r$.
As the sequence is geometric we can use the general formula for the third term...
$$$u3​24r2r=​=u1​r2=37.5r2=0.64=±0.8​$$$
The value of $a$ is negative as the mass moves below the $x$-axis.
Therefore $a=37.5×(−0.8)$.
$a=−30​$


We can use the general formula with $n=6$.
$$$u6​​=37.5×(−0.8)6−1=−12.288​$$$
The $6$th term is $u6​=−12.288​$


Let's first review the total distance travelled when the $3$rd measurement is taken, as shown in the diagram...
$$$S3​​=2×u1​+2×u2​+u3​=2(u1​+u2​)+u3​=2S2​+u3​​$$$
This means all distances before the third term must be $×2$ as the mass must both extend to that distance and return to the $x$-axis.
But when the measurement is taken it only extends that distance therefore we don't double the distance for that measurement.
Using that information we can work out the total distance travelled when the $6$th measurement is taken...
$$$S6​​=2×u1​+2×u2​+....2×u5​+u6​=2(u1​+u2​+....+u5​)+u6​=2(S5​)+u6​​$$$
We can find the value of $S5​$ using the formula for the sum of $n$ terms of a geometric sequence.
However, realise that we must use the positive values of the $y$-coordinate as we are finding the total distance travelled. Therefore we must use $r=0.8$.
$$$​=2(1−(0.8)37.5(1−(0.8)5)​)+37.5×(0.8)5=264.408​$$$
The total distance travelled when the $6$th measurement is taken is $264.408​$ as required.
